You could always just try it out and stop if you see it negatively affecting you. Your dosage is really small.
I was prescribed daily with a higher dose (I forgot) and I ended up sleeping too much, which made me miss meals and eat too little, which all compounded my depression. It was a bad doctor that prescribed this. I now take it as needed. Another thing that works for me is to take .5 to 1mg at night and it lasts a little during the day.

She's an atheist/non-religious but when I talked to her about gay marriage (I'm not out, engaged in a hetero relationship right now) she said they shouldn't be married because they can't have kids. I then said if straight couples who were infertile shouldn't get married, and she simply said that was a good point. She didn't disagree with it because of religion or hatred, but I think she just never thought about it and was ignorant. She doesn't have any gay friends that she knows of, and grew up in Japan where being gay was kind of ignored by society.

I meant to say that they carry larger sizes than myself. I think thrift stores carry lots of Mediums (obviously...!). Being an outlier sucks sometimes. My size is usually "as smallest as I can find" and a lot of stores (Old Navy, for example) won't carry that because of a larger bodied clientele. My family lives in Japan and their sizes are great and I can usually wear their mediums.

As someone on the skinnier side (00/0), I often find thrift store jeans to carry larger sizes. I have to admit I don't browse thrift stores too often (I try not to buy a lot of clothes), and I never shop at Hollister but I appreciate this and was able to find my and my SO's sizes.
I'd like to add that they have sales very often in case you aren't sure what to buy. I used to have a Gap credit card and I rarely saw the site not have a sale.

Same experience when I went to Japan. The busier parts had great McCafes, and for cheap, which is hard to come by in Tokyo. The one I went to was in Harajuku, and it was multi story I think? It was a small menu. Got the cappuccino and it was great.

The back lot of Wurster 178 is generally open has a silent agreement with graffiti artists to not take down their work, so you can paint back there probably but it would be outside.

Violence is wrong and it seems to have discredited the opinions of these protesters. But you can't say civil disobedience won't do shit.
Since people don't seem to be looking at historic protests when looking at this situation, an example you might've seen are worker strikes. Their opinion does get heard, and unions are formed, and people are a little less marginalized, a little more paid, and a little more insured.

The discomfort of someone being late to work is incomparable to what the cause actually is about? Police brutality is more important than that, I think we can both agree.
If you look at successful protests/marches throughout history, they did not get there by being subtle and uninterruptive.
I totally don't agree with causing violence and damage to property but something like shutting down a freeway does make sense to me a bit. They got their message heard on the news and told the police that they do have power in their actions. If all that they caused in return was a few people being late, which would be pretty few since this was like at midnight, I think the bigger message is more important.

It's because for a protest to be successful, there should be a disruption to an every day thing like the use of freeways (or taking over golden bear cafe last week). That way, their voice can be heard because they can't be heard from traditional methods. In this case, they were silenced because the police and court system havent been listening. That's what my understanding of it is.

I had a friend explain to me that it was due to a possible future career. Not ashamed of protesting, but doing things like going on the freeway is illegal and it can affect them in the future. Getting filmed for doing so can also cause an arrest in the future. He was in no way intending to cause violence, though.
edit: Loving the downvotes on this and my other responding comments. It really shows maturity on a topic that needs to be talked about. Remember that downvotes are not for disagreeing with someone's comments, but for spam, etc. Seriously disappointing.

I would try for different classes. A lot of them are filled even for art majors. Crashing can be an option. At some point, an email is sent out with what classes still have openings, since there are some that are less popular and don't get the required amount of students.
There's a children's illustration DeCal. Also, she should email Dee Levister if she needs a code to a specific class. I would look at the DeCals once they're up, though.

It's unhealthier to be 15lbs underweight than to be 15lbs overweight, especially in terms of heart conditions. The less you eat, the more likely your blood pressure will lower (in a bad way) and you won't be pumping enough oxygen through your body.

WRITING.TITLE: Just a quick rant about the irony of a test question I got wrong in college.
WRITING.TEXT: I'm taking a Developmental Psychopathology course at my college and on the test, it asks for what the treatment options are for substance abuse problems in adolescents. This test also covers questions about ADHD (among other things) and the great person I am, misread the question and answered it to a T, but thinking it asked about the treatment options for ADHD instead of substance abuse. So I got 0/15 on that. Because my ADHD brain skimmed over the question and made a careless error. And I can't take Adderall anymore because my heart rate is too high. So my lack of ADHD treatment answered it as ADHD treatment options...

I thought about it recently, and someone was saying how it really doesn't matter because who cares if someone knows I'm wearing underwear. Like... big deal, I'm wearing underwear.
I don't go commando because I don't wash my pants every time I work out. Going commando leaves residue, if you know what I'm saying.

They usually say take 2 classes from your major, 1 required class (prereq or whatever you need), and 1 fun class. I did 2 of my major, 1 of my minor, and a DeCal for my first semester, which added up to be 13 units.

You can't diagnose pcos with biopsies (that I know of). An ultrasound is one of the three ways that they detect pcos-- the others being a blood test and just having the physical symptoms. 2 out of the 3 have to show pcos irregularities to be diagnosed.
I had a doctor explain to me that the reason having no periods is so bad is because basically what tissues (egg? maybe?) should be expelled during a period isn't being expelled, so it's kept in the uterus. This builds up and can cause cancerous cells to develop. I might be wrong with the details... But basically my doctor said that having a few periods is much better than none, just so it won't build up.
I know you were saying that you don't want to change your lifestyle, but not choosing a hormonal treatment might do more harm than good. IIRC, you only have to induce the period once or a few times for the cancer risk to lower. So you might not have to be on a medication for a long time or anything. Just something to think about.

WRITING.TITLE: [QUESTION] Is SL 5x5 a full body workout?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm starting SL 5x5 and am used to doing lots of dumbbell exercises per workout (pullovers, biceps curls, db bench press, isolated tricep things, wrist curls and reverse, etc etc) and I feel like the three exercises won't be working out my full body.
For those that have used the program, do you do accessory exercises? Which ones? Before or after the major lifts?
Has a rack for regular barbells, just not one for fixed barbells, which I think is common.

Right... I forgot I had help with that part, too. I'm going to stick to dumbbell squats for now.
Also, I think /u/mikelieman posted it but it seems to be called the Steinborn Lift.

Thanks, that helps :) I haven't been doing goblet squats for that long, and assumed they were similar to dumbbell squats.
I love this subreddit!! It's answers like this thread that focus on learning how to start correctly that make me feel better about not being able to squat an empty bar. My fiance is athletic so it's hard for him to give me pointers on this sort of thing. So I appreciate the novel!

I love my DOMS too. I have a multitude of reasons to not push myself before getting my form down (hyperflexible, shoulder injury, herniated disc in my spine, and possible slight muscle atrophy from a past with anorexia). A year ago, a 3lb dumbbell to do pullovers was intense so I'm weaker than a lot of people's starting out points. Anyways, it's just boring excuses, but I'm just trying to say that 10lbs does make a big difference for my body, and everyone starts off at different points. I'm a pain slut when it comes to DOMS, I just don't want to injure myself.

It's interesting because when I used the bar, I was leaning too forward and felt a lot of weight on my shoulders/back, even with a 35 fixed barbell but didn't feel that much discomfort doing goblet squats. It feels like if I'm too vertical, the barbell will just roll off my back. I think my bodyweight squats are pretty good, though. It's all just a new movement for me. Need to learn how to trust my body.

I was doing goblet squats (I think I did 30lb last week, relatively easily). I also haven't been doing overhead presses, so maybe I should work on that too... More reps it is.
I hope you heal quickly!

I meant to say that there wasn't a rack for the preloaded ones. They're too short to fit on the regular squat rack. [They're like these](http://www.gymdirect.com.au/media/pics/site/imagecache/4/E/4E0915147E1760364D113A08B8AFC6FB.jpg).
That video looks so scary to me. I'm really not used to using my muscles so I'm prone to injuring myself!

I'll do that next time. Thanks!
Today I took it off the rack and was waiting a little bit so I had one end on the ground, making it really hard for me to bring it back horizontally again.
I'm hyperflexible so that kind of movement still feels a little scary (afraid of partially dislocating my shoulder) but I'll definitely do the overhead press way first. If not, I'll do the front squats. Totally forgot about that.

WRITING.TITLE: How do I get a pre-loaded barbell on my shoulders to squat?
WRITING.TEXT:
I tried using barbells today for the first time. The 45lb bar was OKAY but I really think I need to focus on form before that. So, I went down to the preloaded barbells (I think that's what they're called according to the internet?) and used 35lb, but I can't figure out how to get it on to my shoulders. I had some help today (thanks, strangers!) but since there isn't a rack, I'm kind of confused. Also, I bench press using dumbbells but I guess I could use these too. How would I get into and out of position without hurting myself?

I just said that we rescued a 7 year old dog. That means it was not our fault, and we're doing our best to train him. One way to really fuck up a dog is to leave your dog at home.
The last time he got to a dog (didn't hurt the chihuahua, but it was in his mouth), we picked him up and pryed his mouth open, cutting up our hands. The owner was kicking our dog, which didn't help. If you think that putting your dog on its back while in a fight helps, you've never experienced a dog fight. Why are you so against putting dogs on leashes?
A leash won't stop an unleashed dog running up to a leashed dog

This has happened on normal dog walks. We walk around our neighborhood since it would be much less responsible to not give him walks. We've had a dog trainer, different types of muzzles, harnesses, and sprays. All you have to do is use a leash.

Another opinion, but for me I absolutely hate when the pressure is on the front. The sides where my arteries are feel the best to me. My SO is familiar with choking people out (boxing, bdsm), so I go to the point of almost being choked out but not all the way. Although, I'm comfortable enough where I wouldn't freak out if I was choked out. I hate the feeling of lacking air through my throat and would rather there be no pressure on my actual trachea. And agreed with tapping out to make sure it's all okay.

Just because your dog is friendly with other dogs, doesn't mean mine is. We got a rescue who was 7 yrs old, and is unfriendly with dogs. We've been doing our best to help him with it, but he isn't perfect. Every time there's been a problem, it's been with dogs off of their leash running up to our dog. And honestly, retractable leashes are horrible too. Leash your dog for the safety of your own dog, not just what you think is irrational fears of people.

Went twice and didn't go to the temple burn by choice. Exodus ended up being super fast the first year (almost no stopping). Unless you have someone special who passed and something is in the temple, I'd say it would be fine to skip.
